conclusion: To determine when the two objects are farthest apart, we need to analyze the positions of both objects as a function of time.
Object A's velocity \( v_A(t) \) is given by the slope of the line segment in the graph.
Object B's velocity \( v_B(t) \) is also given by the slope of the curve in the graph.
The position of an object at any time \( t \) is the integral of its velocity with respect to time.

premise: Since both objects start from the same initial position (at \( t = 0 \)), we can find their positions by integrating their respective velocities from \( t = 0 \) to \( t \).
conclusion: At \( t = 0 \), both objects are at the same position.

premise: As time progresses, the positions of the objects will diverge based on their velocities.
conclusion: The objects will be farthest apart when the difference in their positions is maximized.
From the graph, we observe that the positions of the two objects will be farthest apart at the point where they have the maximum difference in their positions.

premise: This occurs at \( t = t_3 \), where the position of Object A is greater than the position of Object B.
conclusion: Therefore, the two objects are farthest apart at \( t = t_3 \).
